page.title: 15Dunmow Flitch Ceremony
page.content:
The Dunmow Flitch Trials date from at least 1104 when Lady Juga Baynard founded the Little Dunmow Priory - the church was anxious to reward couples who had lived together in happiness for at least a year and a day. Couples swear in a mock court presided over by a judge and jury and the winning couple is presented with a flitch of bacon as a symbol of good luck. The couple are then paraded through the streets in a special chair.
As from 1855 the custom was moved to the nearby town of Great Dunmow where the trials now take place every four years, but the chair is still kept in the Priory.
This custom is unique to England.
